4 mL microwave vial + stir bar

oDCB 500 µL

120 °C, 72 h, 1000 rpm (precise heating up, 25 min to 119 °C)
Heating off -> 50 °C (47 min) -> taken out
DMF, homogenized w/ spatula

Suction filtration (90 mm 14A filter paper, gently sucked not to dry)
Transfer w/ DMF
Rinse w/ DMF, CHCl3, acetone, MeOH

Supercritical CO2, 2 h
experiments.observationText:
Solubility
TAPP/TMB: undissolved
DMTA/EtOH: undissolved

Appearance
TAPP: Dark purple. DMTA: Yellow
Before heating: Dark susp. Solid amount: KE2 = KE5 > KE3 > KE4
At 118 °C: Dark susp. Film on wall: KE4 > KE3 > KE2 = KE5
After heating:  (KE3–5) EtOH evaporated.
Final solid:  (KE2,3,5) Dark red purple (KE4) Dark purple

XRD: Weak diffraction. No splitting of the second peak. (KE2) Tiny peak at 18°. (KE3) Large peak at 7.8°. (KE4) Three small peaks at 18–22°.

IR
PhNH2:
TAPP: νNH2 3442&3360, νNH 3320, δNH2ot 3240, δNH2 1620, TPP core 1605–1350, νPhN 1284, TPP core 1234–841, γCH+NH 802
KE2–5: νNH(3309), νCH3&νCH, νCO(formyl, KE4>KE3=>KE5=>KE2), νCN(1620). No νNH2. (KE3) νNH2, δNH2

Conclusions
Further condition optimization is necessary.
oDCB is better than TMB.
BnOH is better than EtOH if a microwave vial is used. EtOH can be used in a J-Young valve tube.
AcOH/H2O(2:1) should be somewhere between 20 and 100 µL?
Eclipsed stacking in contrast to Co(tapp).

experiments.observationText:
Appearances
After vortex: (KE14) yellow susp. + black solids (KE15–17) black susp.
After sonic.: green-black susp. (KE15–17) few solids above
After heating: dark susp. + few brown solids above + (KE14) purple solids on wall + large hard solid at bottom + (KE15–17) more brown solids above + purple solids on upper layer droplets. (All) Solvent decreased a little.
After 1st DMF transfer: Dark solids on wall.
Filtrate: Dark brown soln.

XRD
KE14: Similar to Sam's result. First peak split (not shoulder).
KE15–17: Sharp peaks at 5.95, 9.48, 10.73, ...° (different from KE13)

IR
νNH2?, νC=O(KE14 > KE15,16,17), TAPP core, DMTA core

Conclusions
Impure Co(tapp) reproduced Sam's result.
Pure Co(tapp) failed to form COF.
- Minor crystalline component: Co(tapp) coordination polymer or salt?
- Low yield: Incomplete reaction with DMTA?
- Too low solubility hampered the reaction?
- Lower solubility comes from the absence of formyl impurities or from the higher extent of oxidation.

Comments
DMTA does not dissolve in oDCB/nBuOH. More dissolved at high temperature, but precipitate when cooled.
DMTA might be more soluble in oDCB.
90 mm filter paper is better.

experiments.observationText:
Appearance
After vortex: (KE19,20) yellow susp. + dark solids (KE21) dark susp. (KE22) dark red susp. + many solids above
After 2nd vortex:
(KE19,20) dark brown susp. in two layers
(KE21) dark susp. in tow layers + solids above
(KE22) dark red susp. in one layer + many solids above
After heating:
(KE19,20) dark susp. + dark droplets + large solids at bottom + few brown solids above. Solvent decreased.
(KE21) red soln. + dark solids + few dark solids above
(KE22) red soln. + dark solids + large solids in middle + some dark solids above
Final solids: (KE19,20) dark brown (KE21) dark red (KE22) dark violet

PXRD
KE19: Broader and weaker than KE14. FWHM: 0.49, 0.36, 0.41, 0.49° -> Because of skipping Soxhlet or aerobic oxidation of Co(tapp)?
KE20: Sharper than KE19. -> Heating for 72 h causes unwanted reactions?
KE21: Sharper than KE19. FWHM: 0.43, 0.24, 0.34, 0.41°. Sharp impurity signals at 7.45, 8.48, 11.30°.
KE22: Broader and much weaker than KE21. Impurity signals stronger.

IR
KE19: Similar to KE14. νNH2, νCH(more), νC=O, TAPP core, DMTA core. -> Trapped nBuOH or artifact? 
KE20: Similar to KE19. νNH2, νArH, νCH3, νC=O, TAPP core, DMTA core.
KE21: Similar to KE19. νNH2(none), νArH, νCH3, νC=O(less), TAPP-core, DMTA-core. All bands sharper.
KE22: Similar to KE21. νNH2(more), νArH, νCH3, νC=O, TAPP-core, DMTA-core(more). All bands broader.

Yield
KE19: 70% (Ref. KE14 68%)
KE20: 63% -> reaction incomplete at 48 h?
KE21: 85%
KE22: 54%

Conclusions
Soxhlet extraction can be skipped for screening purpose.
Reaction time of 48 h is better than 72 h?
Reaction mixture should be cooled fast out of the block bath?
Co(tapp) should be used in a fresh state with little oxidation.
Effect of formylation cannot be estimated because oxidation state is different.
Crystalline side product might be a CoIII(tapp) coordination polymer.
Vortex should be replaced by a stir bar when dioxane is used.
Oxidation to CoIII(tapp) and formation of its coordination polymer is fast in dioxane? Dioxane should be used in air-free conditions?

Conclusions
Tritylated starting material caused lower yield: Slow deprotection?

Conclusions
Ar atmosphere is important to prevent defect formation and achieving good crystallinity.
PDA can form isostructural 3D COF as DMTA.
PDA-based 3D COF is stable against hydrolysis in air or in water. This is because PDA imine is more stable against hydrolysis than DMTA imine. DMTA imine can be stabilized by stacking, but 3D COF probably does not have stacking at imine.
PDA-based 3D COF is unstable in air, probably via oxidative cleavage of imine.
TAPP-Tr4 and TAPP did not form COF efficiently, probably because of low solubility compared to Co(tapp-tr4) and Co(tapp) in TMB/DO. Other solvents should be used.

Comments
H2O should be directly added without touching to the wall.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Elongation from 72 h to 120 h did not improve crystallinity.
Soxhlet does not affect crystallinity, but might affect the yield a little.
Stir bar is not necessary.
Changing from pump x3 to FPT x1 (Ar x2) did not improve crystallinity.
Shortening from 72 h to 48 h might decrease crystallinity a bit, but not clear.
Decreasing concentration from 20 mM to 10 mM produced a tiny amount of impurity.
Changing solvent from TMB/DO(1:3) to oDCB/EtOH(1:1) stopped the COF formation completely. This can be due to the solvent effect or evaporation of EtOH.

Comments
Vortex was necessary to make the system one-phase.
H2O should be added at last because it is heavy.
Co(tapp-tr4) solution became suspension? at cooling.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
63 vs 73: Use of J. Young tube instead of microwave vial prevented solvent evaporation.
At the same time, the yield decreased a lot. Solvent evaporation was playing a vital role in COF formation:
The effective amount of H2O was lowered? TMB/DO ratio was increased? Local concentration was increased?
The amorphous impurity decreased: Solvent evaporation creates amorphous impurity at drying front.
63,73 vs 59: oDCB/DO gave better solubility for SM.
63,64,66 vs 59,65: Impurity was observed: Same impurity with TAPP-Tr4 and DMTA and oDCB. The impurity should come from PNP or TrOH or PNP-Tr.
Impurity did not form when there is excess PDA while it formed a lot with less PDA. Co-crystal of PNP and Co(tapp)?
64 vs 63: 1 eq of PDA resulted in a decreased yield and different IR pattern. The 3D COF is composed of 2 eq PDA.
65 vs 63: 15 eq of PNP resulted in a 2D phase. Low reversibility favors 2D phase?
66 vs 63: BPDA did not form 3D COF.

Comments
Ar replace during FPT should not be done. It generates a significant amount of solid Ar. It impedes with evacuation and might be dangerous when heated.
FPT caused bumping in KE64,65,66. The liquid should be gradually frozen from the bottom?
2nd FPT was conducted with gradually freezing. Almost no bubble was observed at thawing and no bumping occurred.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Less H2O increased yield: Equilibrium shift
Less H2O increased 2D phase: Less reversibility -> kinetic product (2D)
More PNP increased yield a little: Faster reaction?
More PNP increased 2D phase a little: Faster monomer feed -> kinetic product (2D). Transition state is already low energy, but the intermediate is too high in energy -> reversibility does not change here
Further less H2O increased 3D phase a little: Slower monomer feed -> thermodynamic product (3D)
More PDA increased 2D phase: Less reversibility, faster condensation -> kinetic product (2D)
More PDA increased yield: Equilibrium shift, faster condensation

Comments
Co(tapp-tr4)/(oDCB/DO(1:3)) should not be shaken.
1st FPT formed many bubbles, but no bumping. 2nd FPT formed almost no bubbles. Some bubbles generated when sonicated.
Gradual freezing is better than flash freezing? or just due to high boiling point of oDCB compared to TMB?

Conclusions
73 vs 53,59: oDCB slightly favors 2D phase compared to TMB.
Molecular impurity increased.
74 vs 73: BPDA did not form 3D phase.
75 vs 69: PBA increased 3D phase; increased reversibility or slower formation favored thermodynamic product.
Yield decreased: slow formation or competition.
Morphology changed to cubes: modulator effect.
76 vs 68: DMTA and PivOH strongly favors 2D phase compared to PDA and PNP.
76 vs 14: Trityl protection and condition optimization increased crystallinity of 2D phase. 2nd peak intensity also increased: increased crystallite size. But still a little lower than SVG-14. The morphology was similar to that of Yaghi's 2015 Science paper.

Comments
Sonication after FPT is not good because it causes bumping.
Heiman spatula is good for microwave vials, while spoon spatula is good for J. Young tubes.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
81 vs 59,53: Mes/DO 1:4 caused fast evaporation of solvents because of the low boiling point of DO. Crystallinity decreased because of solids were partially above liquid. Yield increased.
81: Crystals degraded after storage in GB (slower than in the air) <- damage by evacuation?
82 vs 63: High concentration did not improve yield because of the competition with water.
82: Large crystal was obtained! Effects of concentration or solvent?
82: Film with aggregated crystals were obtained.
84 vs 83: BnONH2 was not incorporated because blocked linkers remained in the solution. H2O amount should be decreased.

Comments
Uncatalyzed reaction between a tritylamine and an aldehyde started at 100 °C when concentrated. Heating after mixing should be avoided.
Solubility of BnONH3Cl in DO was very low. It should be dissolved in H2O.
613A filter paper can penetrate or trap small particles. 14A filter paper should be used.
Solids at dry front in microwave vials should not be collected.
82: Crystallinity diminshed in GB <- because of irreproducibility of film sample preparation

Conclusions
89 vs 73: EOE increased 2D phase compared to DO. Reduction of Co(III) by alkoxide?
90 vs 73: DMG increased 2D phase compared to DO. Either (i) strong coordination of DO to Co is necessary for oxidation or (ii) Tr+·DO or Tr+–DO–Co complex is efficient as intermediate for oxidation.
91 vs 63: Yield increased by replacing PDA with TFTA. Equilibrium of imine formation shifted by electron-withdrawing groups.
91 vs 63: Product became 2D phase with TFTA from 3D phase with PDA. 2D phase was favored by fast growth due to equilibrium shift.
92 vs 67: Seeding did not increase the 3D phase. Either (i) 3D phase needs something other than kinetic control or (ii) nucleation was faster than growth.

Solubility of Co(tapp-tr4) in EOE is not good.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
105 vs 67: Using DNP instead of PNP caused formation of 3D phase exclusively over 2D phase.
-> Strong acid increases reversibility of imine linkage, which enables thermodynamic control.
105 vs 67: Using DNP instead of PNP increased the yield and solution became almost colorless. Many amorphous solids were formed along with 3D phase. Imine IR band was weak.
-> Strong acid caused precipitation of amorphous Co(tapp)·DNP salt
106 vs 67: Using DO instead of oDCB caused formation of more 2D phase.
-> Polar solvent favors the formation of 2D phase.
107 vs 106: Using 40 mM instead of 20 mM caused no big difference in selectivity.
-> Effects of reversibility and stacking cancelled out?
107: Dark violet color similar to 3D phase. Morphology was similar to KE83 which has red color.
-> color difference between 2D and 3D phase is not because of the structural or morphological difference, but something else.

Comments
Co(tapp-tr4) 23. 3 mg / DO 333 µL caused ~4% volume expansion -> 0.96 eq
104: Capillary could not be efficiently filled with wet solids using needle. A pipet and a wire should be used.
105: Product was suspended. Because of amorphous phase?
105,107: XRD showed no impurities. Leaving solids at surface level was effective?

IR
105:
νC=N very weak <- Co(tapp)·DNP salt?
1600 strong: νC=C(Ar)(Co(tapp)-PDA) & νC=C(Ar)(DNP) & νNH3+
νNO2 (1510, 1280) stronger than KE81 <- DNP remaining

UV-vis-TRS
106: Broad peaks, Soret band not discernable: because of stacking?

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
112 vs 82: Formation of 3D phase was not reproduced. Why?? Same reason as for KE108–111?
114: waiting for IR
115 vs 67: Using pNBA instead of PNP caused higher selectivity toward the 2D phase. Acidity is not important. Phenol and carboxylic acid have some different effects for catalysis or templation.
116 vs 63: Conversion from the 2D to the 3D phase did not occur. Either (i) the 2D phase is kinetically very stable; or (ii) the 2D phase is thermodynamically stable; or (iii) TrOH is necessary for the 3D phase.

Comments
H2O 43.1 µL in PhNO2/DO(1:3) 333 µL was not miscible with a small error of volume. This condition should be avoided.
Gradual and flash freezing do not make any difference for the thawing process. Flash freezing might be better to prevent oxidation.
KE112 showed color change during storage at RT? Tighten after 15 min was not enough and there was leakage?

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Crystal sizes (1–5 µm) were smaller than in the case of 72 h (KE81, 1–12 µm). 72 h is better.
Both top and bottom part contained MOCOF-1 particles of similar morphologies. Both parts should be collected for filtration.
Bottom part contained more Co(tapp)·PNP impurities.
Decomposition of MOCO-1 in the glovebox in 6M3 for 39 days is negligible.
The effects of storage in degassed PhNO2 is unclear.
MOCOF-1 was decomposed by Nafion, probably because of hydrolysis or oxidation because of acidity. Nafion solution should be neutralized.
Core-shell particles were observed after PhNO2 storage. Why?

H-shaped two-piece glass cell

experiments.observationText:
Discussions
Cracking on the catalyst layer was observed after drying. Most of the catalyst detached from the electrode before/during electrolysis. Cohesion is not enough.
Selectivity toward CO2RR at -0.782 V vs RHE was low and decreasing due to the almost complete detaching of catalyst and the background reaction by carbon.
Total Faradaic efficiency was low at -0.432 V vs RHE, perhaps due to capacitive current.
In contrast to Sam's results, gradual decrease of Faradaic efficiency was not observed at -0.432 V vs RHE. This would be due to difference of carbon paper, electrode holder, COF synthesis conditions, PDA linker, or Co(tapp) monomer.
Blank measurement showed very low HER activity at -0.432 V vs RHE, and gradually increased HER activity at -0.782 V vs RHE, both with very low CO2RR activity.

Conclusions
Drop-casting onto Quintech TP-060-T5 should be done with EtOH, a higher amount of carbon black, and/or a higher amount of Nafion.
Stability cannot be discussed because of detaching.
Faradaic efficiency at low potential should be measured at more negative potential than -0.432 V vs RHE.

eCO2RR
(KE130)Electrode: black, cracked, centered
Detaching of black solids observed right after soaking into electrolyte.
Initial CV was noisy, presumably because of bubbles staying on the electrode near the liquid surface. Second CV was taken after lowering the electrode.
CO2 inlet was too deeply inserted, and the CO2 bubbles were hitting the electrode.

(Blank)Electrode: A little centered, non-cracked (15 µL: more centered, a little cracked)

CA1
Current similar to KE132 per mass: ECSA is proportional to catalyst amount, but not to geometrical area. The carbon black area is not fully covered by catalysts.

vs 119: SEM showed uniform texture inside bigger spheres.

The sealing of a microwave vial is not reproducible?
FPT can be used for degassing.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
ASR119 contains 13–25% Co(tapp-f).
ASR119 contains DMF 31% in weight.
ASR119 contains 3.8 wt% excess Co.
Excess Co does not remain in the COF.
The amount of CoIII could not be quantified by NMR. XPS might help.

Electrolysis
FE at -0.482 V vs RHE increased gradually, while current decreasing: Capacitive current is significant at this potential.
At -0.782 V vs RHE:
CO2RR gradually decreased: Decomposition of COF.
HER gradually increased, faster than blank: Activation of impurity.
Initial selectivity difference between two potentials is not clear because of instability.
*Spikes at CV and CA1: Electrolyte touched the holder.

Electrolysis blank
At -0.482 V vs RHE: no increase of current over time. Mainly capacitive/destructive current.
At -0.782 V vs RHE: increase of current and FE over time observed. Destruction of CB/CP.
Mainly HER.
*Aggregation was observed if stirring o/n was skipped.

NMR
pip: [Co(tapp)(pip)2]+, [Co(tapp-f)(pip)2]+ (13%), pip impurities? (9.17, 8.59, 8.23, 7.38, 7.26, 6.62 ppm), DMF (4.4 eq = 31% wt), pip (No [Co(tapp)(pip)2], amide NH not visible)
pip2: [Co(tapp)(pip)2]+, [Co(tapp-f)(pip)2]+ (25%), [Co(tapp)(pip)2], [Co(tapp-f)(pip)2], DMF, pip (amide NH visible, CoIII:CoII = 81:19)
py: [Co(tapp)(py)2]+, [Co(tapp)(py)2], [Co(tapp-f)(py)2]+, DMF (similar intensity), py (amide NH visible, CoIII:CoII = 97:3)
Amide NH is not visible under a high concentration of pip because of proton exchange.
Some tapp-f might be converted to tapp in pip, and Co(tapp-f) might be preferentially dissolved in pip2.
Heating at 100 °C in pip for 30 min caused complete oxidation of Co.
Dissolving in pure py caused oxidation of Co more than pip/DMSO (1:4).

IR
ASR119 vs KE7: CH3 (2922 2855), C=O(1658), 1093, 659: DMF

ESI-MS
Co(tapp-f)

ICP-OES
Co % in weight:
ASR119: 9.35% (calcd. 5.5%)
COF: 6.40% (calcd. 6.35%)

Appearances
After solvent: pale yellow-green susp. + dark purple solids
After acid and degassing: same
After heating: dark red soln. + dark solids at bottom + few solid on the wall above
Filtrate: dark red
Solids: black

In piperidine: dark green susp.
After heating: dark brown susp.
At RT: dark green-brown susp.
After DMSO: dark yellow-green soln.

In piperidine/DMSO: dark green susp.
After heating: dark green soln. + few solids

In pyridine: dark green soln. + solids
After DMSO: same

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Co(tapp) synthesized with Co(OAc)2 contains 2–3 times less formylation than that with CoCl2.
ASR125 contains 7% tapp-f.
ASR125 contains DMF 22% in weight.
ASR125 contains 2.5% CoX2.
Excess CoX2 does not remain in the COF.

Electrolysis
Activity is higher than KE153: More formation of COF and better dispersion because of less formylation, less Co salt, or less oxidation
Selectivity is higher than KE153: Less HER by less impurity. Background HER suppressed by better dispersion and more COF.
Stability is similar to KE153: Stability is not affected by formylation degree nor Co salt counterion.
Activity is lower in KE154c: Slower stirring leads to less dispersion -> Less conduction, less surface sites
Selectivity is lower in KE154c: Less activity -> More significant background HER by carbon black.
Stability is same in KE154c.
Less HER in KE154c: Slower stirring leads to less dispersion of carbon black or Nafion.

Sorption
Higher BET surface area than KE153: More formation of COF because of less formylation, less Co salt, or less oxidation.

ICP-OES
Co % in weight: 6.01% (calcd. 6.35%)
Impurity remaining? Soxhlet should be conducted.

IR
NH weaker, C=O weaker, C=N stronger than KE153 (normalized at C=C): More formation of imine because of less formylation, less Co salt, or less oxidation.
ASR125 vs KE7: CH3 (2922 2855), C=O(1658), 1093, 659: DMF
ASR125 vs ASR119: OAc? (1541)

NMR
[Co(tapp)(pip)2]+, [Co(tapp-f)(pip)2]+ 7%, pip impurities?, DMF (2.8 eq = 22% wt)
tapp-f amount is less than KE153: because of weaker acidity of Co(OAc)2 than CoCl2
KE154c: signal not detected: DMSO S/N > 100: HCO2- < 0.39 µmol = 0.2% FE at -0.88 V

SEM
Similar particle before and after reaction: Co(tapp)X did not completely react.
KE154c: Similar aggregates to KE155c

Appearances
After solvent: pale yellow-green susp. + dark purple solids
After acid and degassing: same
After heating: dark red soln. + dark solids at bottom + few solid on the wall above
Filtrate: dark red
Solids: black

In piperidine: dark green susp.
After heating: dark brown susp.
At RT: dark green-brown susp.
After DMSO: dark yellow-green soln. + few solids

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
No excess Co in precursor this time. No reproducibility.
The product is similar without formylation.
Excluding formylation somehow compromised eCO2RR activity.
Co(tapp) makes incomplete conversion to COF.

Yield
A little higher than KE154 (61% vs 51%): Precursor contained DMF in KE154. 

Electrolysis
KE155 vs KE154
Activity is lower than KE154: Poorer dispersion?
Selectivity is lower than KE154: HER by carbon black. Poorer dispersion?
Stability is similar to KE154: Formylation and dispersibility does not affect stability.

KE155c vs KE155
Activity is lower in KE155c: Slower stirring leads to less dispersion -> Less conduction, less surface sites
Selectivity is lower in KE155c: Less activity -> More significant background HER by carbon black. Longer prior electrolysis -> carbon black more activated.
Stability is same in KE155c.
Less HER in KE155c: Slower stirring leads to less dispersion of carbon black or Nafion.

Sedimentation in the ink is negligible, as confirmed by the dispersion test.
After KE155c, a big bubble was observed in the reference electrode. Resistance might be increased?

Sorption
A little higher BET surface area to KE154: Slightly more formation of COF because of less formylation, less Co salt, or less oxidation.

IR
Similar to KE154: Formylation does not interfere with imine formation so much. Formylated linker is not incorporated to COF, and remained in solution.
ASR118 vs ASR119: OAc? (1541)

NMR
pip: [Co(tapp)(pip)2]+, pip impurities?, ? (4.24, 5.81 ppm) (No tapp-f, DMF)
py: [Co(tapp)(py)2]+, [Co(tapp)(py)2] (OAc broadened?, CoIII:CoII = 80:20, MeOH broadened?)
KE155c: signal not detected: DMSO S/N > 100: HCO2- < 0.39 µmol = 0.4% FE at -0.88 V
Digestion: TPA 1.6 eq, CHCl3? (8.06 ppm), ? (4.56 ppm)
-> Incomplete conversion!

ICP-OES
Co % in weight:
ASR118: 7.38% (calcd. 8.0%) vs ASR94: 12.5–14.0%
COF: 5.75% (calcd. 6.35%) (90.6% purity)

SEM
Similar particle before and after reaction: Co(tapp)X did not completely react.
KE155c2: Chunks, large aggregates even in the electrode.
KE155c: Similar aggregates, partially destroyed

After solvent: dark purple susp.
After acid and degassing: same
After heating: dark red soln. + dark solids at bottom + some solid on the wall above
Filtrate: red
Solids: black

In piperidine: dark green susp.

Ref. KE155 (Co(tapp)·Co(OAc)2, x2 scale)

Reaction
8 mL J. Young tube
Co(tapp-tr4), sonicate
H2O
PDA/(PhNO2/DO(1:3)) 667 µL, sonicate
BzOH
Immediately FPT x3 (< 1e-2 mbar)
Manually stir, sonicate
120 °C (oven), 72 h
RT (on bench), 5 min, tighten x3

Separation
DMF 1 mL
Filter paper (90 mm, 15A) + glass funnel + suction flask (60 mbar, gently sucked not to dry)
Transfer w/ DMF, pipet, spatula x2
Rinse w/ CHCl3 x2, MeOH x2
Fold, wrap by another filter paper, clip, store in MeOH
scCO2 (program 2, 40 °C)
-> Weight, XRD (Cu), SEM (Merlin), IR
-> sorption (N2) -> ICP-OES (Co)

Catalyst ink preparation
4 mL vial
Sample ca. 1 mg
Stir bar (Biotage for 2–5 mL vials)
Carbon black (Vulcan XC-72R) / EtOH / Nafion 117 solution (5% in H2O & low aliphatic alcohol) (1 mg / 0.25 mL / 10 µL, shake, sonicate) 500 µL per mg catalyst
Parafilm, sonicate
700 rpm, o/n
Shake, sonicate

Drop-casting
Carbon paper (Quintech TP-060-T5, 0.7 cm x 1 cm with a connection area, sonicated in EtOH 10 min x2)
<KE156b: Alfa Aesar TGP-H-60 (not Teflon-treated)>
Dispersion 30 µL on each face, dry in air 30 min each
Dry in vacuo o/n
-> SEM (KE156c2)

Electrochemical CO2 reduction
H-shaped two-piece glass cell
Chamber 1: stir bar (Biotage for 2–5 mL vials), reference electrode (porous glass/sat. KCl aq/AgCl/Ag), working electrode, Teflon tube as CO2 inlet, outlet to GC
Chamber 2: counter electrode (Pt foil), open cap
Anion exchange membrane (Fumatech fumasep FAB-PK-130, soaked in 0.5 M NaCl aq and 0.5 M KHCO3 aq)
0.5 M KHCO3 aq, 400 rpm, CO2 19.2 nccm, 10 min, +0.18 bar
Pine potentiostat, Shimazu Nexis GC-2030
CV (20 mV/s x10, 5 mV/s)
CA1 (-1.11 V vs Ag/AgCl, 55 min)
CA2 (-1.41 V vs Ag/AgCl, 55 min)
CV (5 mV/s)

(10/26)
Catalyst ink preparation (c)
6 mL vial with a sealing
Carbon black (Vulcan XC-72R) > 2 mg
EtOH (extra dry) 500 µL / 2 mg CB
Nafion 117 solution (5% in H2O & low aliphatic alcohol) 20 µL / 2 mg CB
Shake, sonicate

4 mL vial with a label
Catalyst ca. 1.08 µmol *0.41 mg
Stir bar (Biotage, for 2–5 mL vials)
CB/Nafion/EtOH 500 µL per 1.08 µmol catalyst
Parafilm, sonicate
200 rpm, o/n

(10/27)
Drop-casting (c)
Carbon paper (Quintech TP-060-T5, 0.7 cm x 1 cm with a connection area, sonicated in EtOH 10 min x2)
Dispersion (sonicated) 30 µL on each face, dry in air 15 min each
Dry in vacuo o/n

Electrochemical CO2 reduction (c)
Pine potentiostat, Shimadzu Nexis GC-2030
Dual chamber H-cell
Chamber 1: stir bar (Biotage for 2–5 mL vials), reference electrode (porous glass/sat. KCl aq/AgCl/Ag), working electrode, gas inlet & outlet (Teflon tubes)
Chamber 2: counter electrode (Pt foil)
Anion exchange membrane (Fumatech fumasep FAB-PK-130, soaked in 0.5 M NaCl aq and 0.5 M KHCO3 aq)
0.5 M KHCO3 aq (8.4 mL in chamber 1), 400 rpm, CO2 19.2 nccm, 1150 mbar

CO2 flow 10 min
CV (20 mV/s x10, 5 mV/s until -1.41 V)
CA (-1.21, –1.31, –1.41, –1.51 V vs Ag/AgCl, 55 min) *I tilted the cell more after -1.21 V.
CV (5 mV/s until -1.41 V, 5 mV/s until -1.51 V)

Rinse the electrode with H2O
-> SEM (c)

Electrolyte 330 uL
DMSO/H2O (25 mM; 3.55 uL / 2 mL) 20.0 uL
D2O 250 uL
Shake
-> NMR

4 mL vial
Solids

Sonicate

ITO/glass plate 1cm x 1cm
60 °C (Al block, Kimwipe)
Dispersion 30 uL
-> SEM (Merlin)
experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Co(tapp-tr4) compared to Co(tapp):
Increases the yield by its higher purity.
Forms COF with less impurity by its higher solubility, purity, and stability against oxidation.
The purer COF gives better eCO2RR activity and selectivity because of high dispersibility.
This effect is more significant at lower stirring rate for ink.

Yield (compared to KE155)
Higher (94% vs 61%): Less Co salt impurity

Electrolysis (compared to KE154,155,154c,155c)
Activity is higher: More formation of COF because of solubility and less oxidation, and more dispersion by the smaller aggregate size.
Selectivity is higher: Higher activity -> Less significant background HER and leak current. Higher purity -> Less HER sites. 
Stability is similar: Impurity or dispersibility does not affect stability.

Higher leak current: ?

KE156 vs KE132b:
Higher current in CV (x1.5), higher initial CO production rate (x1.3): Shorter reaction time for COF synthesis suppresses aggregation? 

KE156c vs KE156:
- Lower current in CV (/1.7), lower initial CO production rate (/1.2):
Slower stirring leads to less dispersion?
Lower COF amount increased loss on the vial wall?
Sample degraded?
- Lower initial CO FE (-5%):
Less activity -> More significant background HER and leak current.
Longer prior electrolysis -> HER more activated.
- Stability is same.

KE156: Few aggregates on both sides after drop-casting.
KE156c: CA1: Bubbles accumulated at the bridge.
CA3,CA4: I extended the integration region.

Sorption (compared to KE155)
Higher BET surface area: More formation of COF because of solubility and less oxidation.
PSD maximum: 2.12 nm (calcd. slip stack square model: 2.09 x 1.77 nm, slip stack rhombic model: 2.15 x 1.89 nm) (cylindr. pores, QSDFT equilibrium model)
Pore volume: 0.762 cm3/g under 2.8 nm pore width

IR (compared to KE155)
Weaker C=O, stronger C=N (normalized at C=C): More formation of COF because of solubility and less oxidation.

ICP-OES
Co % in weight: 5.86% (calcd. 6.35%, 5.78% incl. re-adsorption of moisture)

SEM
KE156c2 (before electrolysis): more dispersed than KE155c2.
KE156c (after electrolysis): similar
KE156ITO-Ir: clear image

Electrolysis b
Some catalyst had permeated to the connection area in drop-casting, which was out of the electrolyte.

NMR
KE156c: signal not detected: DMSO S/N > 100: HCO2- < 0.39 µmol < 0.1% FE at -0.88 V

Appearances
After solvent: dark red soln.
After acid and degassing: same
After heating: pale orange soln. + dark solids
Filtrate: orange
Solids: brown red

experiments.observationText:
Discussions
XRD showed a little lower intensity, SEM showed sheet-shaped particles.
: Lower amount of PDA, higher amount of H2O, or leaking from more perforated septum suppressed COF formation?
IR vs 85: Free NH2? observed, C=N weaker: High amount of H2O hampered imine formation.

Conclusions
A subtle adjustment of conditions such as PDA and H2O amounts is necessary to reproduce efficient formation of 3D-COF in KE53,59,60.
Just increasing H2O is not effective.
It is better to stick to J. Young tubes for reproducibility.

After heating: colorless soln. + black solids on the wall exceeding the liquid level + few solids on the wall above
Filtrate: pale orange
Solids: black

vs 157:
XRD: More intense signals
SEM: More abundant and faceted RD particles, less abundant and smaller spherical particles. No sheet particles.
IR: a little stronger C=N

Conclusions
PhNO2 should be used instead of Mes.

experiments.observationText:
Discussion (compared to KE67)
XRD: weaker 3D phase peaks: reduced reversibility by less H2O
weaker total intensity in XRD, weaker C=N in IR: amorphous increased because of mismatched stoichiometry. 
IR: 3567w & 3553m: dangling free NH2? at defects?

Conclusions
Decreasing PDA amount is not effective to obtain 3D phase selectively.
3D phase is probably composed of 1:2 stoichiometry.

experiments.observationText:
Discussion
XRD (compared to KE146): sharper and stronger 2D phase peaks, stronger 3D phase peaks: increased reversibility by increased PNA.
SEM: tetrahedral particles: I-43m, I23, or I213 spacegroup. PNA worked as surface capping.
smaller particles: PNA worked as a crystal growth inhibitor.
XRD weak intensity & SEM tiny particles: Amorphous phase favored by PNA? coordination to Co? oxidation of Co?

Conclusions
PNA should be increased or changed to PBA to obtain 3D phase more selectively.
The spacegroup of 3D-phase is  I-43m, I23, or I213. (contrary to the previous model)

After heating: pale yellow-green soln. + dark solids + some red solids on the wall above the liquid
Filtrate: pale brown
Solids: red brown powder

experiments.observationText:
Discussion
XRD: peaks weaker than KE67
IR: C=N and fingerprint weaker than KE67
Sc(OTf)3 hampered imine formation even at 0.08 eq.

XRD: No 2D peaks in contrast to KE67
Sc(OTf)3 increased reversibility or hampered imine formation.

Why Sc(OTf)3 hampers imine formation?
Deactivation of amino groups by coordination? -- max. only 0.24 eq should not be so significant.
Formation of insoluble coordination polymer? -- max. only 0.06 eq should not be so significant.
Promotion of oxidation of Co by Tr+?

Conclusions
Sc(OTf)3 might work with Co(tdpp), but probably not with Co(ttpp).

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Co(ttpp) can fabricate a film with a morphology different from Co(tapp). Advantage of Tr protection?
TEM showed 89.0° between 100 and 010 planes -> C4 imine structure. Not C2v imine

Discussion
Similar yield, XRD, IR, SEM of powder: MLG/SiO2/Si does not affect COF formation.
SEM of substrate: Platelets with wide facets facing up?

Comments
Two substrates stuck together, making the central area of the film thin. Substrate should be in a holder or only one substrate should be used.
Film part showed amorphous-like morphology. The solids on the wall at the meniscus level should not be scratched off.

eCO2RR
KE173 vs KE156c:
- Higher current in CV (x2), higher CO IGPR (x1.5)
Electrode deteriorated in KE156c?
COF deteriorated in KE156c?
Lower amount of COF caused more significant loss on the vial wall in KE156c?
- Higher CO IFE (+5%)
Higher activity -> Less significant HER and leak current
- Less stability in KE173
Shorter prior electrolysis -> More room for restructuring

KE173 10 h at -1.41 V vs Ag/AgCl:
CO production continuously decreases over 10 h.
CO FE continuously decreases over 10 h.
HER increases but plateaus at 400 min.

KE173: EIS failed because of too much current (should be less than 1 mA).

KE173b: EIS Ru = 4.5 Ω at -1.21 V, -1.41 V vs Ag/AgCl

KE173b vs KE173:
Much lower CO IGPR
-> Carbon black is necessary to build conduction pathways?
-> Carbon black has other promoting effects? Local hydrophobicity? Morphology of Nafion composite?

KE173b vs KE153blank:
Similar H2 IGPR: Carbon paper is as active as carbon black.

XRD
25.3 Å, 21.4 Å

TEM
Aggregate
Oriented
interlayer spacing not observable due to resolution limit
FFT: aggregate: 25.0–22.8, 21.1–19.3 Å
Single crystallite
image 7: 25.1 Å, 20.9 Å, 89.0°
image 31: 22.7 Å, 18.0 Å, 87.9°
EDX: C, N, Co
SAED: polycrystalline rings, 24 Å, 20 Å

SEM-EDX
(Andres) Al2O3 particles

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Co(tdpp) should be used for 3D-COF synthesis.
Fast deprotection should be suppressed to increase the particle size. (Less & weaker acid, lower temperature)
Fast nucleation should be suppressed to increase the particle size. (Less & weaker acid, lower temperature, less TPA, more & stronger modulator, better solvent)
Purer Co(tdpp) should be used to increase the purity.
DNP remains in the COF.
Water sorption should be conducted with more stable C=N bond.

Discussion
Compared to KE177 (Co(ttpp)):
- Much higher intensity in XRD, much less amorphous phase in SEM: Co(tdpp) prevents oxidation of Co porphyrin by Tr+.
- Smaller particle size in SEM: Faster deprotection causes faster nucleation and decreases the particle size.
C=N much weaker than KE53: higher purity of 3D-phase?
SEM showed few amorphous particles: Co(tdpp)Cl impurity in the SM or excess TPA formed amorphous phase?

XRD & NMR & IR: DNP remains in the COF. Oxidation of Co(III) during workup or hydrogen bonding with imine.

IR-2: C=O more, C=N less, 1505 more -> hydrolysis promoted by capillary force

Sorption
H2O 15 °C: high uptake ~ 680 cm3/g, negative hysteresis
H2O 25 °C: low uptake ~ 220 cm3/g, normal hysteresis
H2O 35 °C: measurements failed
N2: negligible microporosity
XRD-2: low crystallinity
SEM-2: Concave rhombohedra + nanoparticles

Not so vertical uptake: Several different adsorption sites <- Inhomogeneity of oxidation and/or counterions
Evaporation of H2O or presence of H2O caused collapse. 

NMR
1: susp. excess TPA
2: soln. TPA 0.89 eq, DNP 0.52 eq, MeOH? 0.044 eq
89% IMCOF and 11% Co(tapp)·DNP salt

IMCOF forms Co(tapp)·HCl salt which slowly dissolves.

Appearance
Co(tdpp)/oDCB/DO: dark brown-red soln.
Before heating: dark brown-red soln. + few dark brown solids on the wall above
After heating: pale brown soln. + dark solids at bottom
Filtrate: orange brown soln.
Final solids: dark violet powder

Conclusions
Modulator should be added and/or concentration should be lowered to grow larger crystals.

Smaller particle size in SEM:

Conclusions
Water suppresses nucleation, but also suppresses growth.
Longer reaction time helps?
Gradual depletion by microwave vial?
Less acid and H2O should be used at 10 mM.

experiments.observationText:
Discussion
Compared to KE182 (72 h):
Same yield, similarly intense C=N in IR
-> Imine equilibrium is reached at 72 h.
Higher XRD intensity, larger crystal size in SEM, less fNH2 in IR
-> Recrystallization, defect healing, and Ostwald ripening proceeds by imine exchange beyond 72 h.
More COF
-> Why?? Either
(i) Heterogeneous environment at surface?
(ii) IMOF is a kinetic product, and slowly disproportionated into Co(tapp) and COF?

Crystal sized reached 100 µm!

Conclusions
This is the best conditions to obtain large crystals.
Longer heating enables defect healing and Ostwald ripening.

SXRD
Dataset 2 (d02) has a slightly better Rint.
The solvent mask was applied to compensate the diffuse electron density in the voids.
Hooft's y 0.003(6) -> spontaneous resolution.

Two oxygen hydrogen-bonded to each amino group.
O–N 3.106 Å: Occupancy 0.5 (fixed): OH-
O–N 3.269 Å: Occupancy 0.343: H2O (H positions not modelled correctly)

Co-N(ax) distance: 2.0417(14) A -> Co(III).
Ref. 10.1021/ja00808a013: CoII, 2.436 Å; CoIII, 2.060 Å

Theoretical pore (Connolly radius 3.0 Å, without H2O)
Volume: 21565 Å3 * 6.02e23 mol-1 / 12 / 846.84 g/mol = 1.28 cm3/g
Surface: 5471 Å2 * 6.02e23 mol-1 / 12 / 828.82 g/mol = 3311 m2/g
Surface without TPA: 4551 Å2 * 6.02e23 mol-1 / 12 / 731.73 g/mol = 3120 m2/g

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
13C SSNMR agreed with a previous report.
1H SSNMR is not useful.
15N SSNMR agrees with the COF structure.
scCO2 drying causes irreversible aggregation. Dispersion should be made via direct dilution of reaction mixture.
Composition was confirmed with digestion 1H NMR.
BzOH is successfully removed in the workup.
DMSO/D2O/DCl (9:1) is better than 4:1.
COF-366-Co adsorbs water at > 63% RH.
COF-366-Co is slightly damaged by water desorption.
COF-366-Co should be stored in a dry atmosphere at <63% RH.
COF-366-Co is not promising for photocatalytic H2O2 production by ORR.

Discussion
Compared to KE156 (x1/3 scale):
Similar yield (97 vs 94%), XRD pattern, IR
-> Scale-up was successful.

Digestion NMR
A (Brown soln): [Co(tappH4)Cl2]3+, [Co(tappH4)Cl(dmso)]4+ (15% of Co), TPA (2.0 eq to Co)
B (Brown soln): [Co(tappH4)Cl2]3+, [Co(tappH4)Cl(dmso)]4+ (10% of Co), TPA (2.0 eq to Co) 

Dispersibility
Small amount / 500 uL, shaken, sonicated
EtOH small visible particles, gradual sedimentation
MeCN small visible particles, gradual sedimentation
CHCl3 small visible particles, no sedimentation
PhNO2 large particles, fast sedimentation
DMSO medium particles, slow sedimentation
Py medium particles, fast sedimentation

SSNMR
/221216/2: 13C CP-MAS, P15 = 2.0 ms, NS = 25k (100.63 MHz)
Similar to lit. (10.1126/science.aac8343)
Spinning side bands (124 ppm)

/221216/103: 15N CP-MAS , P15 = 6 ms, o/n, (40.55 MHz)
Smoothing: Moving average 10
-46 ppm (imine), -203 ppm (pyrrole?? noise?)

/221220/301: 1H MAS
One broad peak

Sorptometry
H2O: Uptake starts at 63%RH
Some decomposition after 1st cycle
Slight decomposition after 2nd cycle

N2: as(BET) = 1093 m2/g -> much lower than KE156 (2140 m2/g)
Decomposed by water sorption and humidity?

13C-eCO2RR
Mostly 13CO
Trace 12CO <- comes from 13CO2 (99.0% 13C)
13CO 117 ppm in the blank measurement <- Impurity in 13CO2 bottle? Consistent with KE261-2wCB. Certificates states 5725 ppm, which is wrong?

pORR-H2O2
Solar simulator, w/ no SED: No H2O2
810 nm w/ BnOH: No H2O2
No activity or product deomposition

Filtrate: orange-red soln.
Final solids: brown-red fine powder

Electrode200-2spare: no aggregation

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Aerogel without TEBA was successfully synthesized.
Smaller macropores may be obtained by increasing TPA or increasing concentration.

Comments
15 min would be enough for drying after drop-casting.
Aggregation in 1st drop-casting is not desirable, but how to prevent?

Discussion
Compared to KE203 (TEBA 1 eq):
Similar yield, XRD, SEM
-> COF aerogel can be obtained without TEBA.

Compared to KE183 (TPA 2 eq):
Thinner and more fibers, smaller macropores in SEM
-> Higher amount of TPA causes faster COF growth, and forms networks faster than compact aggregates are formed.
Larger network in SEM
-> Aerogel structure was more maintained thanks to more fibers.
Similar crystal sizes in SEM
-> Higher amount of TPA does not affect the nucleation so much, thereby does not affect crystal size, either.

Compared to KE156 (ttpp, TPA 2 eq):
More C=O, less NH2 in IR
-> Defects or surface dangling groups

eCO2RR
Compared to KE219 (TPA 2 eq, MeCN, denser network):
20% better activity <- within uncertainty?
similar selectivity, similar stability
SEM: similar morphology to KE219, original network not maintained
-> Network structure was disassembled during mixing with carbon black and Nafion.
-> Network structure is too weak.

Sorption
Weight 7.7 mg -> 7.0 mg after outgassing
More macropores than KE156 -> Aerogel is hierarchically porous.
SEM-2: Less macropore -> collapse by capillary force

NMR
TPA 2.0 eq
-> Defects or surface dangling groups is not so many.

Appearance
Before H2O: dark brown-red soln.
After H2O: same
After FPT: same
After heating: dark red gel
After RT: same 
Filtrate: pale orange soln.
Final solids: brown-red fluffy solids

Drop-casting 1st face: slow permeation, aggregation
Drop-casting 2nd face: fast permeation, no aggregation

experiments.observationText:
Discussion
Compared to KE202 (PhNO2):
A little higher yield
-> Lower polarity of oDCB than PhNO2 favors more imine formation and coordination?
A little more COF in XRD & SEM, less NH2 and more imine in IR
-> Either
(i) Lower polarity of oDCB than PhNO2 favors more imine formation than coordination.
(ii) Worse solvation by oDCB promoted kinetically controlled formation of COF by stacking.
Less amorphous particles in SEM
-> Amorphous particles in KE202 are Co(tapp) coordination polymers or salts. 
IMCOF XRD peak intensities match with simulation better
-> Fewer guest molecules in IMOF. Why?

Compared to KE181 (DNP ~0.5 M, H2O ~2.7 M):
Lower yield, less amorphous particles in SEM, less nitrophenol in IR & NMR
-> Amorphous particles in SEM are Co(tapp)–DNP salts. Salt formation was suppressed by weaker acidity.
Less PNP in IR & NMR & XRD
-> PNP is more easily removed in workup.
Higher COF/IMCOF ratio in XRD & SEM & IR & NMR
-> Either
(1) Imine formation is thermodynamically preferred to coordination because of lower H2O amount.
(2) COF growth is kinetically enhanced compared to IMCOF growth because of lower H2O amount.

Conclusions
Lower solvent polarity increases the total yield of COF & IMCOF.
Lower solvent polarity prefers imine formation to coordination.
Deprotection kinetics should be suppressed
Imine formation kinetics should be suppressed.
Imine formation and coordination thermodynamics should not be changed.
Solid formation starts right after the addition of PNP.

15 min would be enough for drying after drop-casting.
Aggregation in 1st drop-casting is not desirable, but how to prevent?

Discussion
Diluted sol is colloidally unstable due to agglomeration.

Aggregates -> Deprotonated Nafion cannot disperse COF NPs. Conductivity might be lost by grain boundaries.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
2,4-DNBA does not so powerfully induce MOCOF-1 formation.
Oxidation of MOCOF-1 under air by acid could not be confirmed under these conditions because of unintentional oxidation in the control sample.
Digestion is faster with (DCl/D2O)/DMSO 1:4.
MeOH in NMR -> scCO2 rinse is not enough or 2,4-DNBA is partially replaced by MeO.
RMOF with partial oxidation is still unstable under air.
Decomposition under air is not a simple hydrolysis.

Discussion
XRD: MOCOF+ COF (ref. KE218 MOCOF-1)
Either
- Insolubility of 2,4-DNBA hampered reproducibility.
- Addition of 2,4-DNBA before freezing prefers MOCOF to COF.

Digestion 1H NMR:  0.49 2,4-DNBA (ref. KE220 0.51 2,4-DNBA)
Oxidation of Co was already complete during heating and normal workup in KE220.

Solubility of 2,4-DNBA is only 0.15~0.3 M at 120 °C.

PXRD-2: IMOF peaks weaker, COF peaks similar

IR-3: C=O increased. Hydrolysis?

NMR-3: 1.01TPA, 0.47 2,4-DNBA, 0 MeOH, ? (4.60s, 7.48d, 8.08s), solids
-> Not simple hydrolysis. 4-Aminophenyl group was oxidized to 3-hydroxy-4-aminophenyl? Catalyzed by Co(II) or porphyrin? Before or after hydrolysis? What is the insoluble solid?

After 1 d: No change
Filtrate: brown soln.
Solids: red-brown fluffy solids
Digested: dark brown soln. + few solids
Digested B: very dark brown soln.
NMR-3: dark brown soln, solids

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
CNP gives the hybrid with higher yield, higher purity, and smaller particles.
Cobalt centers are mainly Co(III) according to magnetometry.
The sample purity is supported by ICP-OES.
Sample gradually decomposes even during handling with care.
Sample decomposition creates larger pores.

Discussion
Compared to KE229 (PNP)
Higher yield
-> Why?
Less phenol in NMR, IR
-> No oxidation by CNP. Only dinitroaryl acids cause oxidation.
Smaller particles in SEM, initial precipitation
-> CNP decreases particle size by faster nucleation by stronger acidity.

Magnetometry
Difference in 1 T and 7 T <- Al foil and sample and/or sample holder contain ferromagnetic impurity
χM·T = 0.10 emu K mol-1 at 300 K, 7 T, corrected with Pascal's constants
LS from EPR
Ref. Co(TPP)(2-MeHIm) (LS) (10.1038/s41467-019-10357-z): χM·T = 0.57 emu K mol-1 at 300 K, 100 mT, corrected with Pascal's constants
-> 18% Co(II)

For accuracy:
Diamagnetic correction should be done using porphine expt. value (10.1016/s0020-1693(00)85301-3)
Honda-Owen method should be applied for ferromagnetic correction (requires Al blank data for different fields)
Gelatin capsule should be completely filled to ensure centering of the sample within Al foil.

Sorptometry
Lower uptake, BET SA than KE53
-> Sample decomposed during storage and measurements.
Another peak at 3.0 Å
-> Sample decomposition caused formation of larger pores.

calcd. Co(tapp) 0.90TPA-imine 0.11CNP: 7.02%

More MeOH
-> scCO2 rinse with samples under fillers is not good?
Too low initial weight, too high final weight
-> Error in the initial weight?

Soxhlet can remove PNP.

Conclusions
Hybrid single crystal growth up to 100 µm is reproducible.
PNP and/or DNB are important to prevent COF formation.
Better beam line should be used for SCXRD.
Vials should be sealed with electrical tape, and preferably with aluminium pouch for shipment. An aluminium pouch sealer will arrive later.

Higher yield, more COF in XRD & SEM, more C=N in IR
-> Imine equilibrium shifted because of fresh DO.

Compared to KE229 (H2O 90 eq, PNP 1.2 M, DNB 0.6 M):
Lower yield, more COF in XRD & SEM, more TPA in DNMR
-> Kinetic formation of COF is prominent at lower PNP and/or DNB concentrations even when imine equilibrium is less favored.

No spots in SCXRD
-> Either
(i) Too weak beam intensity
(ii) Packaging was not tight

The amount of MeOH for scCO2 exchange should be minimized.
DNB is effective to prevent COF formation.

Compared to KE228 (x1/3 scale):
Similar PXRD pattern, SEM shape, DNMR, IR, yield
-> Upscale was successful.
Smaller particles
-> Heterogeneous nucleation is promoted in a larger scale.
MeOH remained a lot more
-> scCO2 diffusion was incomplete because of the larger amount?
-> putting samples under fillers is not good?
CNP remained more
-> rinsing was insufficient because of the larger amount?
The yield is similar
-> no H2O adsorption because of the presence of MeOH, although 60% RH shows 48% w/w H2O adsorption in KE178.

NMR-2: 0.87TPA, 0.26CNP, 4.5MeOH

IR-2: Less MeOH, H2O. No increase of C=O, no decrease of C=N
-> MeOH was removed by evacuation. No hydrolysis by capillary force
Compared to KE228: Still more MeOH, more CNP
-> MeOH cannot be completely removed  

XRD-2: 1st & 2nd peak stronger, 3rd peak weaker
-> Intensity depends on guest solvent molecules
Compared to KE228: Still weaker intensities, 3rd peak much weaker
-> Due to residual MeOH, CNP, less packing density, smaller particle size

4: Main peak intensity 6800, higher background when normalized at main peak -> partial decomposition in desiccator o/w and glovebox for 1 year

-> Diamagnetic Co(III)(tpp)(amine)2
MAS: δiso = 8872(5) ppm, (e2qQ/h)/[1 + ηq2/3]1/2 = 2.69(10) MHz -> Matching Co(TPP)MeIm2 in the literature (doi: 10.1021/jp972043g)
Static: |δzz-δiso| = |δCSA| =  1763 ppm, e2qQ/h = CQ(quad) = 3 MHz -> Matching to Co(Por)MeIm2 in the literature (doi: 10.1021/jp972043g)

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
CNP 1.2 M gives higher yield than 0.6 M.
CHCl3 is not necessary to remove excess TPA and solvent molecules.
scCO2 is necessary to remove solvents without pore collapse.
scCO2 or CHCl3 is necessary to remove DMF.
CNP is present as main counteranion before CHCl3 and scCO2.
scCO2 or CHCl3 removes CNP anions.

Discussion
Compared to KE228 (CHCl3, scCO2, CNP 1.2 M):
Weaker PXRD
-> Solvent removal under vacuum caused pore collapse by capillary force.
Lower yield, particles in filtrate?
-> Either
(i) Higher concentration of CNP causes formation of large aggregates which can be filtered.
(ii) Higher concentration of CNP promotes RMOF formation somehow.
Similar crystallite size in SEM
-> CNP concentration did not affect crystallite size
More DMF in DNMR, IR
-> CHCl3 or scCO2 removed DMF
Less MeOH in DNMR
-> Vacuum removed MeOH
No PhNO2, DO, DNB, no excess TPA in DNMR
-> Solvent molecules and unreacted TPA were exchanged by DMF and MeOH during rinsing. CHC3 is not necessary.
More CNP in DNMR
-> CHCl3 or scCO2 removed CNP anions.
Either
(i) scCO2 placed HCO3- or MeCO3- as counteranions, which were decarboxylated at ambient conditions after scCO2 and thus not visible in 13C NMR & IR.
(ii) CNP anions were removed by deprotonation of amino groups, which were protonated by moisture after scCO2.
(iii) CNP anions were removed by carbamate formation of amino groups, which were decarboxylated by ambient conditions after scCO2 and thus not visible in SCXRD & IR.
(iv) HCl in CHCl3 replaced CNP.

After RT: brown susp., dark solids on the immersed wall
Filtrate: brown susp.?
Filter paper: many particles left

NMR: dark red soln.

Conclusions
KE229 is a better condition for 1 µm single crystals. TPA amount should not be increased.
CHCl3 rinse is not necessary.
The loss of PNP anion is not because of HCl in CHCl3.

trace COF in PXRD, SEM.
-> TPA amount was too much.
Similar yield.
-> Increasing TPA amount does not help getting higher yield. COF formed just instead of MOF.
Less PNP in DNMR
-> Loss of PNP is not because of HCl in CHCl3.
Similar DNMR
-> CHCl3 is not necessary to remove solvent molecules.

XRD at Dinnebier's Cu diffractometer vs Lotsch's Co diffractometer (large-hole)
Larger Kapton background
-> The beam size of Dinnebier's Cu diffractometer is larger than the size of our sample press.
S/N ratio not so different

XRD with large-hole sample holder vs small-hole sample holder at Lotsch's Co diffractometer
No difference in Kapton background
-> The beam size of Lotsch's Co diffractometer is smaller than the hole of the small-hole sample holder.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Crystal growth for SCXRD requires 6 days, H2O 170 eq, 120 °C or other modulators or concentrations for Ostwald ripening.

Discussion
Compared to KE232 (more H2O, less PNP, no DNB, lower temperature, longer time):
No COF in PXRD & SEM, less TPA in DNMR
-> DNB, PNP, and possibly high temperature preferred formation of the hybrid.
Smaller crystal size in SEM
-> Either
(1) Lower amount of H2O hindered Ostwald ripening.
(2) Shorter reaction time hindered Ostwald ripening.
(3) Higher temperature caused the evaporation of H2O and thus hindered Ostwald ripening.
-> Higher concentration of PNP and higher temperature did not drastically promote Ostwald ripening.
Smaller yield
-> Due to suppressed kinetic formation of COF.

Compared to KE254 (different reaction conditions, x20 scCO2 with additional MeOH)
Less MeOH (0.09 vs 0.59) in DNMR
-> Either
(1) More cycles and less initial MeOH facilitated exchange with scCO2. The counterion after scCO2 is always OH-. Previous observations of MeO in DNMR comes from solvent MeOH.
(2) o/n storage in a vial caused escape of MeOH vapor. The counterion after scCO2 can be OH- or MeO-.

After RT: dark red soln., solids on the immersed wall, hard solids at the bottom

Solids: dark violet solids, films, small particles stuck on the filter paper

NMR: dark red susp.?

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
6 days or excess DMTA+H2O is necessary for growing large crystals.

Discussion
Compared to KE233 (DMTA 2 eq, H2O 170 eq, PNP 0.6 M, 120 °C, 6 days, weaker suction, scCO2 x20):
Weaker PXRD, cracks in SEM
-> Stronger suction caused drying of the solids and concomittant amorphization by capillary force?
A bit smaller crystal size in SEM
-> Longer reaction time and/or excess DMTA+H2O helps crystal growth by Ostwald ripening.
Slightly less DMTA in DNMR
-> Slightly higher H2O/DMTA ratio and higher temperature slightly disfavored imine formation thermodynamically.
Less yield
-> Small particles left by incomplete Ostwald ripening was trapped in filter paper.
Less PNP in DNMR
-> PNP was more efficiently removed by more scCO2 cycles.
Less MeOH (0.09 vs 0.59) in DNMR
-> Either
(1) More cycles and less initial MeOH facilitated exchange with scCO2. The counterion after scCO2 is always OH-. Previous observations of MeO in DNMR comes from solvent MeOH.
(2) o/n storage in a vial caused escape of MeOH vapor. The counterion after scCO2 can be OH- or MeO-.

~10% Cl in SEM-EDX
-> Contamination from glassware

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
eCO2RR performance of highly aggregated COF-366-Co in KE155c was not reproduced.
Reproducible eCO2RR performance of highly aggregated COF-366-Co is determined from KE180, 260, 261.
Reproducible background HER behavior is determined from KE153blank, 261blank, 261blank2.
Background HER shows highly varied activity for each electrode.
COF-366-Co NPs suppress background HER, thus increasing CO FE.
COF-366-Co large aggregates suppress background HER less efficiently, which contributes to the low CO FE.

Discussion
Compared to KE260 (parallel):
Similar XRD, SEM
-> COF formation was reproduced.

eCO2RR
Activity (initial CO evolution rate): KE180, KE260, and KE261 were similar to each other.
-> Use of oDCB in KE180 did not affect COF formation. eCO2RR activity is reproducible.
KE155c showed higher activity
-> Either 26.7 µmol scale COF synthesis or ink preparation in 4 mL vial affected eCO2RR activity.
Stability (CO evolution rate at -0.78 V): KE180, KE260, and KE261 were similar to each other.

Selectivity (Initial CO FE): KE180 and KE260 were similar to each other. KE155c showed different behavior. Same reasons as for the activity.
Stability (CO FE at -0.78 V): KE180 and KE260 were similar to each other.

Background HER (H2 evolution rate at -0.78 V): KE153blank, KE261blank, KE261blank2 showed different activity, but similar gradual activation.
-> Background HER is sensitive to tiny differences in electrolysis setup.
Background HER activity is similar to the case of highly aggregated COF-366-Co, but higher than COF-366-Co NPs.
-> COF-366-Co NPs suppress background HER, but highly aggregated ones not.

SEM-EDX blank2: no suspicious elements
-> HER is not because of accumulation of impurities.

KE261-2wCB:
13C: Mostly 13CO
13CO 110 ppm in the blank measurement <- Impurity in 13CO2 bottle? Consistent with KE200-2. Certificates states 5725 ppm, which is wrong?
CO evolution rate much higher than KE261, 260, 180, 155c
-> Why? Decomposition under air exposed more active sites? Particle size was too inhomogeneous?

Sorptometry
N2: as(BET) = 852 m2/g -> much lower than KE155 (1643 m2/g)
Decomposed by humidity? Co(tapp) was not pure?

Appearance
Before FPT: pale yellow soln., black solids suspended

After FPT: same

After RT: red-brown soln., solids at the bottom

Filtrate: red-brown soln.

Solids: dark purple~violet solids

Electrode: few large particles in the first drop-casting

Ink-2woCB: dark brown susp.. large dark brown solids at bottom (dispersed by sonication and stirring)

Conclusions
Oxidation to Co(III) in the hybrid framework occurs during reaction.
3,5-DNBA causes a reproducibility problem.

Discussion
Compared to KE227 (Aerobic workup, no ethanol, MeOH for scCO2):
COF in PXRD, SEM

<- Initial precipitation causes inhomogeneous reactions
Weaker PXRD
-> Why?

More MeOH
-> Decreasing MeOH for scCO2 rinse is not effective to avoid remaining MeOH.

Hybrid framework can be formed directly from Co(III)(tdpp).

Conclusions
Slow exchange with scCO2 and higher stirring rate is not effective to exchange MeOH.
Hybrid framework has higher BET surface area than COF-366-Co.
Hybrid framework does not chemisorb CO2 at RT under 760 Torr.
Hybrid framework contains deprotonated amines as counteranions.

Compared to KE228 (5 days, scCO2 exchange speed 4, stir 75%):
Lower yield, more particles in filtrate & filter paper

More MeOH in DNMR
-> Slow exchange with scCO2 and higher stirring rate is not effective to exchange MeOH. Less amount of MeOH should be used.

More CNP compared to others
-> scCO2 x30 cycle is better to remove CNP.

-> Slightly more than 0.15CNP
-> Cl- is not major counteranion

negative uptake in the beginning and desorption branch <- because of tube or instrument

1.5 uptake than KE183 (COF-366-Co)
Similar to the BET surface area ratio

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
Single crystals of the hybrid should be grown with less imine-forming conditions and less nucleating conditions.
Single crystal growth of the hybrid requires only 5 days.
Ostwald ripening is not effective.

Discussion
Compared to KE182 (3 days), KE191 (5 days), KE232 (6 days):
Hybrid/COF ratio in PXRD: KE182 > KE191 > KE291 > KE232.
-> Hybrid/COF selectivity is independent of reaction time, but dependent on other subtle factors. Molecular sieves were saturated in KE182 and KE191?
-> Hybrid and COF do not interconvert over time.
Crystal size in PXRD: KE191 > KE232 > KE182 > KE291
-> Crystal size is independent of reaction time longer than 5 days, but dependent on other subtle factors.
-> Crystal growth is completed in 5 days.
-> Ostwald ripening is not effective.

-> Lower concentration suppresses nucleation.

Crystal size too small or damaged?

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
This synthetic method of the hybrid framework is robust.
NaCl should be avoided.

Discussion
Compared to KE289 (DMF, no NaCl aq, MeOH for scCO2, x20):
Similar PXRD, SEM, TPA amount in DNMR
-> Hybrid framework synthesis was reproduced.
Less CNP in DNMR
-> CNP was partially replaced by Cl-.
Similar MeOH in DNMR
-> MeOH vapor for scCO2 and 30 cycles are not effective to remove MeOH completely.
-> MeOH liquid is better to avoid any drying, and 20 cycles is better to save CO2 and time.
Higher yield
-> Flocculation by NaCl aq ensured filtration of small particles.
Too high yield (115%)
-> Water remained.
-> DMF should be used to remove water.

Sorptometry
N2: as(BET) = 2863 m2/g (R2 = 0.991) -> agrees with KE289 (2836 m2/g, R2 = 0.998)
CO2/N2 uptake ratio similar to KE200: not particularly selective to CO2
CO2 uptake at 298 K, 1 bar: 44.3 cm3/g -> higher than KE289 (35.4 cm3/g)
-> KE289 degraded during storage.

SEM-EDX
289-2 (w/o NaCl): Na 0.20(12), S 0.41(10), Cl 0.28(6) -> 0.15 CNP
Ref. 301-2 (w/ NaCl): Na 0.26(14), S 0.27(5), Cl 0.46(10) -> 0.06 CNP. Cl- present. Na+ unclear
Either
(i) NaCl exchanges some CNP with Cl-.
(ii) NaCl is adsorbed.

Appearance
Before FPT: dark brown-red soln.

After FPT: dark brown susp., solids on the wall above

After RT: dark red-brown susp., solids on the wall above

Filtration was slow.

Filtrate: orange soln.

Solids: dark violet solids, few small particles stuck on the filter paper

NMR: dark red soln.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
A new batch can be used for the hybrid framework synthesis, although a small amount of impurity is included in the product.
Hybrid framework survives at least partially during electrode preparation.
Residual CoII is present as octahedral diamine porphyrin and surface superoxide monoamine porphyrin in ca. 2:1 ratio.
Spin coherence is not promising because of small hyperfine coupling.

Discussion
Compared to KE301 (old batch of Co(tdpp)):
No impurity in PXRD.
-> Impurity came from the old batch of Co(tdpp).
Few large particles in SEM.
-> Impurity in the new batch of Co(tdpp) caused a slight change in nucleation/grothw kinetics.
Small additional peaks in DNMR.
-> Impurity in the new batchof Co(tdpp) caused trace impurity in the product.
Similar PXRD pattern, SEM morphology, DNMR integral ratio, yield
-> Formation of the hybrid framework is not significantly affected by the different batch.

EPR
Component 1 ~67%
rhombic, S = 1/2, I = 7/2
g = [1.973 2.175 2.240]
A = [80 310 101] MHz = [0.0027 0.0103 0.00337] cm-1
gStrain = [0.022 0.07 0.015] -> y component uncertain
Matches with Co tetraarylporphyrin + 2 piperidine in the literature (10.1021/ja00717a018, Figure 5), but hyperfine coupling smaller and rhombic.

Component 2 ~33%
axial, S = 1/2, I = 7/2
g = [1.999 2.045]
A = [38 55] MHz = [0.0013 0.0018] cm-1
gStrain = [0.006 0.008]
Matches with Co tetraarylporphyrin + piperidine + O2 in the literature (10.1021/ja00717a018, Figure 5)

Component 3 (temperature-independent)
symmetric, no hyperfine
g ~ 2.00
impurity? (cf. 10.1039/c5qi00275c)

Ink air-dry PXRD
Weak intensity -> Partially amorphized? not qunatitative. At least not totally decomposed.

eCO2RR (jupyterlab/heck/CAFE/20231018)
Without CB (HEF-114_3a) vs with CB (HEF-114_4a): 1000 times different activity. Hybrid structure does not help in electron transport or decomposed.
hybrid (HEF-114_4a) vs COF (KE219-2): Lower activity. Hybrid structure is less active for eCO2RR or decomposed.
HEF-114_4a: CO + H2 FE > 95% -> No other major products

SEM302e: aggregates -> Conductivity lost by grain boundaries?

Appearance

Before FPT: dark brown-red soln.

After FPT: dark brown susp., solids on the wall above

After RT: pale brown susp., dark brown gel, solids on the wall above

Filtration was fast.

Filtrate: brown soln.

Solids: dark violet spongy solids

NMR: dark red soln.

Supernatant in EtOH/Nafion/KOH: pale yellow-brown soln.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
The porosity of MOCOF-1 is stable in pyridine, 10 mM NaOH aq, water, HCl aq (0.33 eq), and air for 1 day.
The imine linkage of MOCOF-1 is transformed or linker vacancy is created by 10 mM NaOH aq.
MOCOF-1 is stable in the glovebox (4M1 or 6M3, PTFE sealing pad, Parafilm) at RT for 1 month.
MOCOF-1 is stable in the glovebox (4M1, PTFE sealing pad, Parafilm) at 4 °C for 8 month.
MOCOF-1 is not emissive.
NaCl aq should not be used.
scCO2 should be run 30 cycles with MeOH vapor and single filter paper.

Synthesis
Compared to KE302 (1/3 scale x1, NaCl with MeOH, MeOH vapor with scCO2, scCO2 30 cycles):
Similar PXRD, SEM, 1H NMR -> Scaleup successful.
Similar excessive yield -> H2O from NaCl aq remained even though DMF was used.
More MeOH in 1H NMR -> Too large amount of solids in one filter paper?
No CNP in 1H NMR -> Exchanged by Cl from NaCl aq
More Cl in SEM-EDX -> NaCl or HCl adsorbed

N2 sorption
Microporous N2 uptake: C > A > D > E > B (BET: D, R2 < 0.99; E, R2 < 0.995)
A,C,D: Impurities or guest extracted, stable
A vs B: Slight amorphization and TPA defects by HCl
A vs C: Slight amorphization and TPA defects by neutral water more than 10 mM NaOH aq

PXRD A–E
Normalized at wide angle, baseline subtracted
3.8°, 5.5°: D > E > C > A > B
6.7°: A > B > C > D > E
Simulation:
Loss of H2O: 3.8° increase
Loss of TPA: 3.8° increase, 5.5° decrease, 6.7° increase
Correlation between 3.8° and 5.5° -> No loss of TPA or canceled out by change of guests.
No correlation between 3.8° and 6.7° -> Change of guests. Decomposition cannot be judged.

1H NMR
305: Co(tapp) 0.89TPA 8.50MeOH
2A: Co(tapp) 0.83TPA 17.87MeOH  (41% w/w)
2B: Co(tapp) 0.85TPA 15.26MeOH, 8.65 ppm (m)
2C: Co(tapp) 0.67TPA 16.35MeOH
2D: Co(tapp) 0.92TPA 13.16MeOH
2E: Co(tapp) 0.81TPA 14.93MeOH (37% w/w)
A, B, D, E: insignificant changes (<10%) in TPA amount
C: Slight transformation of imine linkages or loss of TPA by NaOH?
3A: Co(tapp) 0.82TPA 0.02MeOH, 10.32 ppm (s)
3B: Co(tapp) 0.79TPA 0.05MeOH, 10.32 ppm (s)
3C: Co(tapp) 0.75TPA ? 0.02MeOH, 10.32 ppm (s), 10.15 ppm (s), 8.65 ppm (m)
Insignificant changes (<10%) in TPA amount

SEM-EDX
Ref. 289-2 (w/o NaCl): Na 0.20(12), S 0.41(10), Cl 0.28(6) -> 0.15 CNP
Ref. 301-2 (w/ NaCl): Na 0.26(14), S 0.27(5), Cl 0.46(10) -> Cl- present. Na+ unclear
305: Na 0.36(4), S 0.29(4), Cl 0.62(9) + Na2SO4 -> Cl- present a lot. Na+ unclear
A: Na 0.13(5), S 0.32(8), Cl 0.21(5) -> Cl- removed by H2O
B: Na 0.11(2), S 0.39(3), Cl 0.48(5) -> Cl- adsorbed from HCl (out of 0.40 eq)
C: Na 0.14(3), S 0.31(2), Cl 0.14(1) -> Cl- removed or not removed by NaOH
D: Na 0.45(5), S 0.43(2), Cl 0.39(6) -> Cl- removed or not removed by py
E: Na 0.49(5), S 0.52(3), Cl 0.50(3) -> Cl- removed or not removed by MeOH and scCO2

Weight
A–E: 12.64 mg, 12.52 mg (12.52*0.82/828.82=12.4 µmol), 11.80 mg, 13.20 mg, 11.47 mg (E: 13.59*0.69/11.47 = 82% purity)
2A: 15.56 mg, 2B: 14.42 mg, 2C: 13.37 mg, 2D: 14.83 mg, 2E: 13.59 mg
Filter paper A–E after scCO2 was cold. -> MeOH remaining
Sorption tube dose: A, 10.9 mg; B, 10.2 mg; C, 9.1 mg; D, 11.3 mg; E, 9.8 mg
After outgassing: A, 6.9 mg (63%); B, 6.4 mg; C, 5.4 mg (59%); D, 6.2 mg; E, 6.8 mg (69%) -> D,E: loss of MeOH
After taken out from the tube: A, 7.02 mg; B, 6.61 mg; C, 5.67 mg; D, 6.12 mg; E, 6.37 mg -> A,B,C: inconsistent
Empty tube weight difference after cleaning: A, -1.5 mg; B, -0.9 mg; C, -1.7 mg; D, -1.0 mg; E, -1.0 mg -> D, E: Due to base bath 3 days (-1.0 mg confirmed by a blank test). A,B,C: errors in the initial tube weight -> recalculated with new tube weight - 1.0 mg.

PXRD F–H
2F: slightly more intense than 2E -> not much decomposition
3F: background and signals both less intense than 2F, capillary looked thinner than others -> capillary diameter is not uniform.
2F,3F,3G,3H: blank subtracted and normalized by wide-angle background: almost unchanged -> MOCOF-1 is stable in glovebox (4M1 or 6M3) at RT or freezer for 1 month.
4B: first peak 7100 (2B: 7600), low-angle tail +40% intensity when normalized at the first peak -> slight decomposition in glovebox for 8 month or outside o/n.
4E: first peak ~70% intensity, same low-angle tail intensity when normalized at first peak -> within the uncertainty of PXRD, no significant decomposition in glovebox (4M1) at 4 °C for 8 month.

HP-PXRD
Ambient: Intensity ratio different from PXRD-KE305-2A. The lattice parameter did not change significantly. -> PTM penetrated? Looks possible with the SCXRD model (aperture 13 Å). Ref. A MOF with an aperture diameter of 14 Å can penetrate silicone oil AP 100 (10.1021/acs.inorgchem.2c04428).
stable up to 4000 bar <- PTM penetration?
Small intensity decrease after going back: capillary deformation, sample movement?
Bulk modulus: 3rd BM equation in PASCal, B0 ~ 7.68 GPa (recalculation needed for pressure uncertainty) -> in the range of typical rigid MOFs (4–40 GPa), probably contains a contribution from PTM (bulk modulus 1 GPa).

UV–vis–NIR absorptance
Soret band: 457 nm, broad, asymmetric
Q bands: 551, 586 nm
-> porphyrin feature. Exciton coupling should be confirmed by comparison with molecular model compounds.

UV–vis PL
Peak at 687 nm, also in blank measurement -> MOCOF-1 is non-emissive

Before FPT: dark brown-red soln.
After FPT: dark red susp., solids on the wall above
After RT: brown soln., dark red gel, solids on the wall above
Filtrate: green-brown soln.
Solids: dark red-purple solids

NMR: dark red soln.

A~C before o/n: red-purple susp.
D: dark brown susp.

A,C after o/n: colorless soln., dark red solids
B: red susp., dark red solids
D: yellow-green susp., dark solids

Filtrate A,B,C,E: colorless soln.
Filtrate D: yellow-green soln.

NMR 2A–E, 3A–C: dark red soln.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
The protonation of Co–anilido center by 3,5-DNBA could not be confirmed by ssNMR.

Synthesis
Compared to KE310 (CNP):
A little botryoidal phase in SEM, insoluble solids in DNMR
-> 3,5-DNBA caused formation of insoluble [Co(H-1tapp)]n(3,5-DNBA)?

Compared to KE227 (PhNO2):
A little botryoidal phase in SEM, insoluble solids in DNMR
-> DNB/PhNO2 caused formation of insoluble [Co(H-1tapp)]n(3,5-DNBA)?

Some Cl in SEM-EDX
-> CoCl2 impurity from the precursor?

ssNMR
1H: similar to KE242-2. Broader signals because of lower frequency. T1 = 50–100 ms <- bulk paramagnetism from residual Co(II)?
13C: similar to KE242-2. Broader signals because of lower frequency.
15N: similar to KE242-2. ~5 ppm shift? Inconclusive. (ref. >10 ppm shift by protonation)
59Co: ~30 ppm shifted compared to KE242-2. Too small shift, inconclusive (ref. >100 ppm shift between Im and MeIm and 50 ppm uncertainty in 10.1021/jp972043g). Not similar to 15N and 13C -> Not due to bulk paramagnetism from residual Co(II)

Appearance
Before FPT: dark brown-red soln.
After FPT: dark red susp., white & dark red solids on the wall above, many dark solids at the surface level
After RT: dark red susp., solids on the wall above
Filtrate: brown soln.
Solids: dark red-purple solids
NMR: dark red soln., black solids

PXRD
2: Lower intensity (57% 1st peak, 67% 2nd peak, 63% 3rd peak, 61% 4th peak) -> ~40% decomposition over 4 month in GB and during ssNMR

Synthesis
Compared to KE305 (NaCl aq, scCO2 with 2 paper, stir 75%, 20c, no vacuum):
Less Cl in SEM-EDX, more CNP in NMR
-> NaCl aq caused the exchange of CNP with Cl- in MOCOF-1.
Less MeOH in NMR
-> New workup procedure is effective to remove MeOH.

Yield higher than 100%
-> Water (~8%) + something?

EPR
HF-EPR: very complicated. Some impurities?
After 5 months: Sample decomposed.

experiments.observationText:
Conclusions
The reason for the irreproducibility in BMI-034 is unclear.
Membrane filtration is better than paper filtration for MOCOF-1 synthesis.
A membrane filter should be placed over the o-ring.
Vacuum drying could be skipped.
The purity of Co(tdpp) is important for MOCOF-1 synthesis.
MOCOF-1 is not stable even in GB at 4 °C with a sealing pad and Parafilm.

Discussion
Compared to KE310 (MeOH, filter paper, 40 µmol x 2 scale, CoCl2 impurity):
Less broad peaks in NMR
-> Because of new Co(tdpp) or new DCl/D2O
More TPA (1.00) in NMR
-> Previously CoCl2 caused defect formation?
More CNP in NMR
-> EtOH is ineffective in removing CNP compared to MeOH?
No MeOH in NMR
-> scCO2 more effectively removed MeOH on a membrane filter compared to a filter paper.
-> Vacuum might not be necessary.

Membrane rapture
-> Membrane should be placed over the o-ring.

Compared to BMI-034 (paper filtration):
Much higher intensity in PXRD
-> The product was somehow decomposed in BMI-034
Similar concave-like structure in SEM
-> This level of concaveness is not due to decomposition

Appearance
Before FPT: dark brown-red soln.
After FPT: dark red susp., dark red solids on the wall above, large dark solid on the wall at the liquid surface level
After RT: dark brown susp., solids on the wall above, large dark solid on the wall at the liquid surface level
Filtrate: orange soln., few red-brown solids
Solids: dark red-purple solids
NMR: dark red soln.

Out of GB: very dark purple solids

Dispersion test-2
DMSO: brown soln. + dark solids (fast sedimentation)
MeCN, EtOH, H2O: pale brown soln. + dark solids (fast sedimentation) 

PXRD-2
Much lower intensity: decomposition in GB
Ref. KE-305-4E: No decomposition in GB (4M1, 4 °C) for 8 months
Ref. KE-242-4: Only slight decomposition in GB for 1 year
-> Faster decomposition by unknown reason. Irreproducible.

PL-2
Weak emission at 687 nm, excitation maximum at 454 nm, ns-scale lifetime (not IRF corrected)
-> emission from MOCOF-1? (ref. Co(III)TMPyP5+ 630 nm, 434 nm, 0.75 ns & 1.83 ns; DOI:10.1016/j.inoche.2014.10.029)
Emission overlapped with background peaks, high background in decay

Filter paper (90 mm, 15A), glass funnel, suction flask (60 mbar, barely open), 2 mL long plastic pipet, long metal spatula, critical point dryer (Leica EM CPD300, pre-saturated w/ MeOH vapor)
(Cooled down, 5 min, tightened) x3
DMF 3 mL each, mixed w/ pipet
Filtered w/ pipet, spatula & DMF (excluding the solids above the original liquid surface, suction stopped before drying up) 
Rinsed w/ MeOH
Folded, clipped, and stored in MeOH
scCO2 (stir 100%, exchange speed 4, 30 cycles)
Vacuum (>1 h, <1.0e-1 mbar to <1e-2 mbar): 2.5 h
Kept in a desiccator, minimizing contact to air (RH 55%)
20 mL glass screw vial (weighed), metal spatula, 2 mL plastic tube for PXRD, 1.5 mL glass vial with PTFE-sealing screw cap for NMR, ø1.2 cm carbon tape on Al stub for SEM
Crushed, mixed w/ spatula
-> Weight
-> PXRD (ø1.0 mm No.14 glass capillary, Stoe StadiP @6B11, Cu Kα1, 1.5° to 50°, 3 deg/s)
-> SEM (Sputter-coating: carbon tape, Al stub, Leica EM ACE600, Ir ~6 nm from 30°. Imaging: Zeiss Merlin, 1.5 kV, WD 4.5 mm, 100 pA)
-> 1H digestion NMR (0.5–1 mg, DMSO-d6 440 µL, DCl/D2O(35% w/w) 110 µL, sonicated 5 min, RT 4 days)
Into glovebox (PTFE sealing pad, Parafilm, 4M1, evacuated 10 min, cycled w/ Ar x4, 4 °C)
experiments.observationText:
Appearance
Co(tdpp): brown-red solids
TPA: white solids
CNP: white fluffy powder
After sonication: dark red solution
After FPT: dark red-brown liquid + dark solids
After heating: brown solution + brown-red solids
Filtrate: brown solution -> colorless solution
After scCO2: dark wine-red crumbs (filter paper was cold, some solids leaked out of filter paper)
NMR: dark red solution

Discussion
Compared to KE-312 (1/6 scale, 1 Schlenk bomb, NMR digestion 2 days):
Bimodal particle size distribution in SEM: Inhomogeneous nucleation in large-scale
A new peak at 8.65 ppm (m, 0.104H) in NMR: Unknown species. Because of 4 days of digestion?

Conclusions
Backup synthesis was successful.

DMTP: white powder
CNP: old ThermoScientific bottle, white fluffy powder; new Aldrich bottle, off-white less fluffy powder
After sonication: dark red solution
After FPT: dark red-brown solution <- Unusual. Why is there no precipitation after the CNP addition? (cf. KE-311, 306, 250)
After heating: dark brown suspension
Filtrate: dark brown solution
After scCO2: dark green-brown flakes (filter paper was cold)
NMR: dark brown suspension

Some solids undigested: Amide polymer formed?
Amorphous in PXRD, prisms and spheres in SEM: Amide polymer did not crystallize or the formation was inefficient

Conclusions
Amide analogue requires different synthetic conditions
